query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 In su l’estremità d’un’alta ripa 2 che facevan gran pietre rotte in cerchio, 3 venimmo sopra più crudele stipa;
query.error: **English:** 1 On the edge of a high cliff 2 made of large broken rocks in a circle, 3 we came upon a more cruel slope;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 e quivi, per l’orribile soperchio 5 del puzzo che ’l profondo abisso gitta, 6 ci raccostammo, in dietro, ad un coperchio
query.error: **English:** 4 and there, because of the horrible stench 5 that the deep abyss cast forth, 6 we drew back behind a large tomb,
query.result: 4 and ðær, ðurh ðone egeslican oferflowan 5 ðæs stences ðe se deopa grund geworpe, 6 we us bewunedon, on bæc, to anum hlæwe,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 d’un grand’ avello, ov’ io vidi una scritta 8 che dicea: ‘Anastasio papa guardo, 9 lo qual trasse Fotin de la via dritta’.
query.error: **English:** 7 where I saw an inscription 8 that said: ‘Pope Anastasius I guard, 9 whom Photinus drew from the straight path’.
query.result: 7 micles byrgenes, ðær ic geseah awriten 8 ðis gewrit: ‘Anastasius se papa heolde, 9 ðone ðe Fotin lædde of ðære rihtan wege’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 «Lo nostro scender conviene esser tardo, 11 sì che s’ausi un poco in prima il senso 12 al tristo fiato; e poi no i fia riguardo».
query.error: **English:** 10 "Our descent must be slow, 11 so that the senses may grow accustomed 12 to the foul air; and then we shall not care."
query.result: 10 "Ure nidergang sceal wesan stede, 11 swa ðæt ðæt gesihð mæge gewunian 12 ðone fule stenc; and ðonne ne bið him nan yfel."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Così ’l maestro; e io «Alcun compenso», 14 dissi lui, «trova che ’l tempo non passi 15 perduto». Ed elli: «Vedi ch’a ciò penso».
query.result:
**English:**
13 Thus the master; and I said to him, "Find some way 14 that the time may not pass lost." And he: "See that I am thinking of that."
**Old English:**
13 Swa ðe láreow; and ic ða cwæð, "Sumne cræft", 14 ic him sæde, "gemearca ðæt se tíma ne síe 15 forloren." And he ða cwæð: "Gesyhð ðæt ic ðæs hogie."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 «Figliuol mio, dentro da cotesti sassi», 17 cominciò poi a dir, «son tre cerchietti 18 di grado in grado, come que’ che lassi.
query.error: **English:** 16 "My son, within these rocks," 17 he then began to say, "are three circles, 18 each smaller than the last, like those you left.
query.result: 16 "Min sunu, innan ðam stane," 17 ða ða ongann secgan, "synd ðreo ringas, 18 an ðære wisan ðe ðu ða ðær forlete."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Tutti son pien di spirti maladetti; 20 ma perché poi ti basti pur la vista, 21 intendi come e perché son costretti.
query.error: **English:** 19 All of them are full of evil spirits; 20 but so that the sight of them may suffice you, 21 understand how and why they are constrained.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 D’ogne malizia, ch’odio in cielo acquista, 23 ingiuria è ’l fine, ed ogne fin cotale 24 o con forza o con frode altrui contrista.
query.error: **English:** 22 Of all wickedness, which hatred acquires in heaven, 23 injury is the end, and every such end 24 either by force or fraud brings sorrow to others.
query.result: 22 Of ealre yfele, ðe hatung on heofonum getið, 23 unriht is ende, and ælc ende swylc 24 oððe mid gewealde oððe mid facne oðrum geswencð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Ma perché frode è de l’uom proprio male, 26 più spiace a Dio; e però stan di sotto 27 li frodolenti, e più dolor li assale.
query.error: **English:** 25 But because fraud is man's own special evil, 26 it is more displeasing to God; and therefore the fraudulent 27 are placed lower, and greater pain assails them.
query.result: 25 Ac forðæmðeðeðeofrisisðæsmannesagenmal, 26 hitbiððeð Godeðeðmare; andðærforðeðastandaððæð 27 ðafræcednymen, andðamareðeðheoraðasæleðð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Di vïolenti il primo cerchio è tutto; 29 ma perché si fa forza a tre persone, 30 in tre gironi è distinto e costrutto.
query.error: **English:** 28 The first circle is entirely for the violent; 29 but because force is done to three persons, 30 it is divided and constructed into three rings.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 A Dio, a sé, al prossimo si pòne 32 far forza, dico in loro e in lor cose, 33 come udirai con aperta ragione.
query.error: **English:** 31 To God, to himself, and to his neighbor he applies 32 force, I say, to them and to their possessions, 33 as you will hear with clear reasoning.
query.result: 31 Gode, himsylfum, his nehstan he mæg 32 wyrcan geweald, swa ic secge be him and be heora æhtum, 33 swa ðu gehyrst ðurh scearpne andgit.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Morte per forza e ferute dogliose 35 nel prossimo si danno, e nel suo avere 36 ruine, incendi e tollette dannose;
query.error: **English:** 34 Death by force and grievous wounds 35 are inflicted on one another, and on their possessions 36 ruin, fires, and harmful thefts;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 onde omicide e ciascun che mal fiere, 38 guastatori e predon, tutti tormenta 39 lo giron primo per diverse schiere.
query.error: **English:** 37 therefore murderers and all who strike evilly, 38 ravagers and plunderers, the first circle torments 39 in different bands.
query.result: 37 þanon manslagan and manfre man, 38 herewæðan and hreðran, ealle hearmcwide 39 on ðam ærestan hring ðurh mislice heapas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Puote omo avere in sé man vïolenta 41 e ne’ suoi beni; e però nel secondo 42 giron convien che sanza pro si penta
query.error: **English:** 40 A man can commit violence against himself 41 and his own possessions; and therefore in the second 42 circle it is necessary that he repent without avail,
query.result: 40 Mæg mon habban on him sylfum manful hand 41 and on his agenum godum; and forðæm on ðæm oðrum 42 ymbhwyrft bihofað ðæt he butan bote hine sylfne hreowsige,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 qualunque priva sé del vostro mondo, 44 biscazza e fonde la sua facultade, 45 e piange là dov’ esser de’ giocondo.
query.error: **English:** 43 whoever deprives himself of your world, 44 squanders and destroys his wealth, 45 and weeps there where he should be joyful.
query.result: 43 swylc swa hine sylfne berædað of eowrum middangearde, 44 forspild and forleosað his fæhðe, 45 and wepeð ðær ðær he sceolde beon glæd.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Puossi far forza ne la deïtade, 47 col cor negando e bestemmiando quella, 48 e spregiando natura e sua bontade;
query.error: **English:** 46 One can use force against the deity, 47 with the heart denying and blaspheming it, 48 and scorning nature and its goodness;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 e però lo minor giron suggella 50 del segno suo e Soddoma e Caorsa 51 e chi, spregiando Dio col cor, favella.
query.error: **English:** 49 and therefore the lesser circle seals 50 with its mark Sodom and Cahors 51 and those who, scorning God with their hearts, speak.
query.result: 49 and forðæm se læssa ymbhwyrft insegligað 50 mid his tacne Sodoman and Cahorsan 51 and ða ðe, God forhogende mid heortan, sprecað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 La frode, ond’ ogne coscïenza è morsa, 53 può l’omo usare in colui che ’n lui fida 54 e in quel che fidanza non imborsa.
query.error: **English:** 52 Fraud, by which every conscience is bitten, 53 a man can use against one who trusts in him 54 and in one who does not store up trust.
query.result: 52 Seaðe, ðurh ðæt ælc gewiht bið biten, 53 mæg mon brucan wið ðone ðe him on treoweð, 54 and wið ðone ðe treowe ne gehealdeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Questo modo di retro par ch’incida 56 pur lo vinco d’amor che fa natura; 57 onde nel cerchio secondo s’annida
query.error: **English:** 55 This way of going backward seems to be caused 56 by the bond of love that nature makes; 57 therefore in the second circle are nestled

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 ipocresia, lusinghe e chi affattura, 59 falsità, ladroneccio e simonia, 60 ruffian, baratti e simile lordura.
query.error: **English:** 58 hypocrisy, flattery, and those who practice witchcraft, 59 falsehood, theft, and simony, 60 pimps, barrators, and similar filth.
query.result: 58 licetung, flæsclic lufu and wiccan, 59 leasung, ðeofð and sygewif, 60 strýnan, ceap and swylc unriht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Per l’altro modo quell’ amor s’oblia 62 che fa natura, e quel ch’è poi aggiunto, 63 di che la fede spezïal si cria;
query.error: **English:** 61 For the other love is forgotten 62 that nature makes, and that which is added later, 63 from which special fidelity is created;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 onde nel cerchio minore, ov’ è ’l punto 65 de l’universo in su che Dite siede, 66 qualunque trade in etterno è consunto».
query.error: **English:** 64 therefore in the smaller circle, where is the point 65 of the universe on which Dis sits, 66 every betrayal is eternally consumed.
query.result: 64 forðæm on ðam læssan rince, ðær ðæt is 65 ðæs middangeardes stede ðær ðe Dis sitteð, 66 ælc ðara treowa bið on ecnysse forloren.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 E io: «Maestro, assai chiara procede 68 la tua ragione, e assai ben distingue 69 questo baràtro e ’l popol ch’e’ possiede.
query.error: **English:** 67 And I: "Master, your reasoning proceeds very clearly, 68 and you distinguish very well 69 this abyss and the people who possess it.
query.result: 67 And ic: "Lareow, ðin ræd geliðeð swiðe scearp, 68 and ðu ðisne stede and ðis folc ðe her wunað 69 swiðe wel todælst."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Ma dimmi: quei de la palude pingue, 71 che mena il vento, e che batte la pioggia, 72 e che s’incontran con sì aspre lingue,
query.error: **English:** 70 But tell me: those in the slimy bog, 71 whom the wind drives and the rain beats, 72 and who clash with such harsh tongues,
query.result: 70 Ac sege me ðis: ða on ðam wætan slæde, 71 ðe wind drifeð and ðe regn beateð, 72 and ða ðe feohtan mid swa biteran wordum,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 perché non dentro da la città roggia 74 sono ei puniti, se Dio li ha in ira? 75 e se non li ha, perché sono a tal foggia?».
query.error: **English:** 73 why are they not punished inside the red city, 74 if God is angry with them? 75 And if he is not, why are they in such a state?"
query.result: 73 hwi ne beoð ða innan ðære readan byrig 74 gewracode, gif God him gram is? 75 And gif he him hold, hwi synd hi swa gewæhte?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Ed elli a me «Perché tanto delira», 77 disse, «lo ’ngegno tuo da quel che sòle? 78 o ver la mente dove altrove mira?
query.error: **English:** 76 And he said to me, "Why does your intellect wander so far 77 from its usual path? Or where else is your mind gazing? 78 Do you not remember those words
query.result: 76 And he said to me, "Why does your intellect wander so far 77 from its usual path? Or where else is your mind gazing? 78 Do you not remember those words

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Non ti rimembra di quelle parole 80 con le quai la tua Etica pertratta 81 le tre disposizion che ’l ciel non vole,
query.error: **English:** 79 with which your Ethics discusses 80 the three dispositions that Heaven does not want, 81 incontinence, malice, and mad
query.result: 79 with which your Ethics discusses 80 the three dispositions that Heaven does not want, 81 incontinence, malice, and mad

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 incontenenza, malizia e la matta 83 bestialitade? e come incontenenza 84 men Dio offende e men biasimo accatta?
query.error: **English:** 82 bestiality? And how incontinence 83 offends God less and incurs less blame? 84 If you consider this judgment carefully,
query.result: 82 bestiality? And how incontinence 83 offends God less and incurs less blame? 84 If you consider this judgment carefully,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Se tu riguardi ben questa sentenza, 86 e rechiti a la mente chi son quelli 87 che sù di fuor sostegnon penitenza,
query.error: **English:** 85 If you consider this judgment well, 86 and bring to mind who they are 87 who are doing penance outside,
query.result: 85 Gif ðu ðeosne dôm wel gecnawest, 86 and ðu ða gemyndge ða ðe ðær 87 butan ðære healle ðone hreowe doð,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 tu vedrai ben perché da questi felli 89 sien dipartiti, e perché men crucciata 90 la divina vendetta li martelli».
query.error: **English:** 88 you will see clearly why they are separated from these wicked ones, 89 and why divine vengeance hammers them with less torment.
query.result: 88 ðu gesyhst ðonne sona hwi ða synfullan 89 sind fram ðam oðrum gedælede, and hwi ða godcundan wracu 90 ða ðe ðær sind ðurh ðone hreowe swiðor swingað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 «O sol che sani ogne vista turbata, 92 tu mi contenti sì quando tu solvi, 93 che, non men che saver, dubbiar m’aggrata.
query.error: **English:** 91 O sun, who heals every troubled sight, 92 you satisfy me so when you rise, 93 that, no less than knowing, doubting pleases me.
query.result: 91 Eala ðu sunne ðe gehælst ælce gedrefde gesihðe, 92 ðu me gefylst swa ðonne ðu astihst, 93 ðæt, na læs ðonne witan, me tweoðung licað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Ancora in dietro un poco ti rivolvi», 95 diss’ io, «là dove di’ ch’usura offende 96 la divina bontade, e ’l groppo solvi».
query.error: **English:** 94 "Turn back a little further," 95 I said, "to where you say usury offends 96 the divine goodness, and untie the knot."
query.result: 94 "Giet ðu ðe hwilwendan," 95 cwæð ic, "ðær ðu sægst ðæt wuocher 96 Godes gesetnysse gram wære, and ðone cnotan unbind."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 «Filosofia», mi disse, «a chi la ’ntende, 98 nota, non pure in una sola parte, 99 come natura lo suo corso prende
query.error: **English:** 97 "Philosophy," she said to me, "to one who understands it, 98 notes, not just in one part alone, 99 how nature takes its course
query.result: 97 "Þæt is ðæt ðe ðu scealt witan, ðæt ðeos woruld is gesceapen of Godes wisdom and of his mihte, 98 and ðæt ðeos woruld is gerihtod æfter ðære godcundan gesceafte, 99 and ðæt ðeos woruld is geondþrungen mid Godes mihte,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 dal divino ’ntelletto e da sua arte; 101 e se tu ben la tua Fisica note, 102 tu troverai, non dopo molte carte,
query.error: **English:** 100 from the divine intellect and from its art; 101 and if you properly note your Physics, 102 you will find, not many pages later,
query.result: 100 and ðæt ðeos woruld is geondþrungen mid Godes wisdom, 101 and ðæt ðeos woruld is geondþrungen mid Godes godnesse, 102 and ðæt ðeos woruld is geondþungen mid Godes fægernesse,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 che l’arte vostra quella, quanto pote, 104 segue, come ’l maestro fa ’l discente; 105 sì che vostr’ arte a Dio quasi è nepote.
query.error: **English:** 103 that your art follows that [of nature], as much as it can, 104 as the student follows the master; 105 so that your art is, as it were, the grandchild of God.
query.result: 103 and ðæt ðeos woruld is geondþungen mid Godes sōðfæstnesse, 104 and ðæt ðeos woruld is geondþungen mid Godes rihtwīsnesse, 105 and ðæt ðeos woruld is geondþungen mid Godes mildheortnesse."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Da queste due, se tu ti rechi a mente 107 lo Genesì dal principio, convene 108 prender sua vita e avanzar la gente;
query.error: **English:** 106 From these two, if you recall 107 Genesis from the beginning, it is fitting 108 to take their life and advance mankind;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 e perché l’usuriere altra via tene, 110 per sé natura e per la sua seguace 111 dispregia, poi ch’in altro pon la spene.
query.error: **English:** 109 and because the usurer takes another path, 110 he despises nature for himself and for his followers, 111 since he places his hope in something else.
query.result: 109 and forðæm ðe ðe wucor-mon oðre wisan healdeð, 110 for ði selfne and for ða his folgeras 111 forsihð ða gesceafte, ðonne he on oðer set ða hyht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Ma seguimi oramai che ’l gir mi piace; 113 ché i Pesci guizzan su per l’orizzonta, 114 e ’l Carro tutto sovra ’l Coro giace,
query.error: **English:** 112 But follow me now, for the journey pleases me; 113 for the Pisces are darting above the horizon, 114 and the Wain lies all over the Chariot,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 e ’l balzo via là oltra si dismonta».
query.error: **English:** 115 and the cliff is dismounted over there beyond.
query.result: 115 and ðæt beorg ofer ðone sæ ðær ofer astiho.
